--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@c...> wrote:
> Hi!
> 
> I've been hacking away at a simple OCR demo using DelphiNEAT. I let
NEAT 
> see a picture (7 x 14 pixels) of a letter and let it choose which
letter 
> it thinks it is (out of 26 letters). Thus, I have 7*14=98 inputs +
1 
> bias. And I have 26 outputs. Creating a connection from every input
to 
> every output leads to 99*26 = 2574 connections per network. 
> 
> Now, I've tried a method where I add X random connections instead of
the 
> full 2574 connections, but so far, the results are depressing.
> 
> Does anyone have an idea for a better method?
> 

Shimon Whiteson here at UT has been working on a method of feature
selection that slowly adds new inputs over the course of the run and
has had some initial success.  You might want to try this with your
high-input domain as well.  He generally found it beneficial to start
out with very few inputs attached and let NEAT attach inputs randomly
through a special mutation that connects a disconnected input to all
the outputs.  The rate of that mutation is somewhere between 0.05 and
0.2 in his experiments but it's still an empirical question what's
best.  It would be interesting to see if it helps in OCR.

ken
